subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] The principles of my dictionary
msgSnippet: ... Yes, though I might rather spell {bQtVl} -- I think a consistent spelling rule should be found for syllabic /l/, writing it either {l} or {Vl} in all
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay skrev:
> Benct Philip Jonsson wrote:
>
>> The main features of the AtOx spelling are:
>>
>> The lexical sets LOT-CLOTH-THOUGHT are all written with
>> the QS letter {Q} [^1] and TRAP-BATH-FATHER are all
>> written with {a}. The resulting -- hopefully simple --
>> spelling rule for speakers who merge LOT-CLOTH-THOUGHT-
>> FATHER (i.e. most North Americans) is as follows:
>>
>> The default spelling for /A/ is {Q} (Ox), but spell it
>> with {a} (At) where the TO spelling is _a_ without a
>> following _u_ or _w_.
>
> Okay, I think seeing some concrete examples would help, so
> I've come up with my own (now that I've thought your
> proposal over & understand it better).
>
> The word _thought_ is pronounced by most Americans with
> the same vowel as the word _palm_, what QS represents as
> /A/. Under this spelling reform proposal, _thought_ would
> be spelled as /TQT/. (I realize there is an abbreviation
> for _thought_, but just pretend there isn't.) Likewise,
> _bought_ is spelled /BQT/, _bottle_ is spelled /BQTl/,
> _ox_ is spelled /Qks/, and so fourth.

Yes, though I might rather spell {bQtVl} -- I think a
consistent spelling rule should be found for syllabic /l/,
writing it either {l} or {Vl} in all instances. I'm partial
for {Vl}, since the pronunciation with syllabic /l/ may be
seen as an automatic reduction of the alternate /yl/
pronunciation.

> Americans will have to be careful with words like
> _father_, however. If you pronounce the word with a /A/
> sound, but the word is spelled in TO with an _a_ you will
> have to apply a special rule. (I don't need this rule
> because I am from Boston, & can hear the difference--lucky
> me!) So _father_ is spelled with an _a_, and not followed
> by _u_ or _w_, so you spell it /faDar/. _Paul_ is also
> spelled with an _a_, but it is followed by an _u_, so you
> spell it /pQl/.

Exactly. That's what I said, isn't it?

The rub, which I hadn't really appreciated yet, is the TO
spelling _al_, which may correspond to all of /Ol/, /O/,
/Ql/, /Al/, /al/, with some of the alternatives (except /al/
varying by accent! _talk_ is always /tOk/ but e.g. _salt_
varies between /sOlt/ and /sQlT/ in RP and between /sOlt and
/sAlt/ in GAE. The spelling would have to vary between /Q/,
/Ql/, /al/ even in AtOx spelling, and I'm afraid no reliable
rule to choose between {Ql} and {al} can be given for LOT-
FATHer megers.

>
>
>> One possible reform would be to write FOOT-GOOSE alike
>> with {U} and use {u} for /ju/: it would make another
>> major difference between British and American English
>> less disturbing: in words like _tune, duke, suit, nude_
>> (i.e. where 'long _u_' follows _t, d, s, n_ and at least
>> theoretically _z_) Britons pronounce _u_ as /ju/ but
>> Americans pronounce it as /u/, which would make a
>> spelling without an explicit {j} desirable. Moreover some
>> accents in Britain have a true diphthong /IU/ wherever
>> other accents have 'long _u_', including words like
>> _lute_ and _rude_, so that for them a spelling with a {j}
>> in these words will be as inappropriate as a spelling
>> which renders _u_ in _tune_ and _lute_ differently. To
>> abandon Read's {j_u} ligature would however change word
>> outlines radically, and the required spelling rule is
>> simple as is:
>>
[snip -- see below for new formulation!]
>>
>> Americans will have to remember that {j} after {t, d, n}
>> is silent, and to insert it appropriately, much as non-
>> rhotic speakers have to insert {r}. For speakers of /IU/
>> accents QS spelling was and will be rather illogical, but
>> they will have to defer to the majority.
>>
>
> What if we just never used /j/ before /IU/? Wouldn't that
> be a simpler rule for everyone to follow?

It would. The rub is that there is no /IU/ letter in QS.
Thus my contemplated reform in the use of letters #39 and
#40, which however I feel would be too radical to be
acceptable to most people. Hence I instead offer a rule for
Yod-droppers where to insert a silent {j}. Since
pronunciation ranges from /tuzde/ over /tjuzde/ to /cuzde/
my dictionary will use the {ju} spellings, especially as the
other two pronunciations historically derive from the /ju/
pronunciation. The Yod-droppers' rule for mapping TO
spellings to QS spellings is quite straightforward:

- where TO has _u, ue, ui, eu_ or _ew_ corresponding to /u/
after _t, d, th, s, l, n_ write {ju}.

The older formulation should be scratched since I forgot
that word-initial //lju// behaves differently depending on
whether it follows after a consonant or not, unlike
//rju//, as well as forgetting the _ui, eu_ and _ew_ TO
spelling variants.



> I can't think of an instant where that would cause
> confusion, except at the beginning of a word, in why case
> use the /j/: /junYtad/ /ju tri/. Though I guess even at
> the beginning you could leave out the /j/.

Why would/should that case be exceptional if there is an
'{IU}' letter? If there isn't such a letter it just won't
work: a spelling like {tuzde} will be absurd to those saying
{cuzde}, which are in the majority outside the US and
Canada. Therefore the spelling must be {tjuzde}, with
adjustment rules for those saying /tuzde/ and /cuzde/,
unless QS users can agree on spelling both FOOT and GOOSE
with #39 and spell historical //ju// -- all instances of TO
long _u_, _ui, eu_ and _ew_, even in words like _rule_ if
those still using /IU/ shall be accomodated -- with
#40. Suchb an agreement is however unlikely, seeing how
# small
a minority /IU/ users are.

> You spelling proposal is attractive. Americans can still
> use their ear to spell words except for words in the PALM
> lexical set, which I am to understand is very small.

Exactly, only about 80 words, not counting uncommon foreign
names, and it corresponds to those cases where /A/
corresponds to TO _a_ not followed by _l, r, u_ or _w_, so
it can be learnt by rule.

> I assume that if British spell all PALM words and all BATH
> words with /a/, we will have consistent spelling;
> likewise, I assume consistent spelling if British speakers
> use /Q/ for both THOUGHT and LOT lexical sets.

Yes, that's the idea. Also Americans pronouncing CLOTH words
with /O/ -- mainly Easterners -- would have to make an
adjustment to 'unphonetic' spelling.

>
> I think my dictionary could be used if this spelling
> reform is adapted. It separates out words by the LOT,
> TRAP, and THOUGHT sets. It does not separate out words in
> the BATH lexical set. Nor does it separate words in the
> CLOTH lexical set. However, I think if all the PALM words
> are changed to /a/, and all the LOT and THOUGHT words are
> changed to /Q/, we get the desired spelling.

Yes, we should, though eventually of course all
changed words would need to be checked by hand
against the LPD.

> Paul

/BP 8^)>
--
Benct Philip Jonsson -- melroch atte melroch dotte se

No man forgets his original trade: the rights of
nations and of kings sink into questions of grammar,
if grammarians discuss them.
-Dr. Samuel Johnson (1707 - 1784)
